<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/fed-makes-a-hawkish-pivot-in-a-bid-to-tame-inflation?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Behold, the Fed-Tailed Hawk
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/fed-makes-a-hawkish-pivot-in-a-bid-to-tame-inflation?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="A hawk standing on top of the Federal Reserve building " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/bfe4676b86845cf573a14dc00bbd8854c6788361-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Francis Scialabba, <a href="https://unsplash.com/@joshuadan">OSHUA DANIEL</a>/Unsplash, Rudy Sulgan/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the Fed flipped the bird: It signaled a <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/fed-will-aggressively-dial-back-its-monthly-bond-buying-sees-three-rate-hikes-next-year.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">major pivot</a> from a dovish monetary policy (keeping interest rates low, letting the economy run hot) to a hawkish strategy (raising interest rates, slowing down economic growth) in a bid to tamp down surging consumer prices.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The central bank said it will reduce its economy-juicing, bond-buying program at double the pace it had originally announced in early November. When it stops purchasing bonds altogether, which will likely be in March, it plans to begin hiking interest rates to cool down the economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">And how many hikes will there be? </strong>Most of the Fed’s 18 officials see at least three rate increases next year, which shows how worried they’ve become about inflation in just the last three months. In September, half of Fed officials believed they wouldn’t have to hike rates at all until 2023.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Inflation has replaced the Covid economic crisis at the top of the Fed’s “must tackle ASAP” list. Here’s why:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Consumer prices rose at their fastest pace in 39 years in November, and it wasn’t just due to volatile goods, like food and energy. Items across the economy, from rents to home furniture, also rose a concerning amount.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>And this week, producer prices gained at their </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/producer-prices-ppi-inflation-record-f5da5f63-f7bc-45cc-8abd-24a23c30cde9.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fastest pace on record</a></span><span>. Higher prices paid by producers often trickle down and hit consumers’ wallets.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At the same time, job gains have been strong and the unemployment rate has plunged to 4.2%, the lowest level since the pandemic began. “We are making rapid progress towards maximum employment,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> For months, Powell stressed that inflation was “transitory” and related to quirks of the economy reopening. Now he’s sounding a different tune. “The risk of higher inflation becoming entrenched has increased. I don’t think it’s high at this moment, but I think it’s increased,” Powell said. Cue the hawkish pivot.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GOVERNMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/house-speaker-nancy-pelosi-says-members-of-congress-should-be-allowed-to-trade-stocks?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Pelosi Says, ‘Let Them Trade Stocks’
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/house-speaker-nancy-pelosi-says-members-of-congress-should-be-allowed-to-trade-stocks?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Nancy Pelosi speaking" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/284c17951ffbbf02c803eef9c631f066b24c66c2-6782x4521.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Drew Angerer/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nancy Pelosi believes that if she wants to YOLO into AMC or Peloton, that’s her right as a citizen in a free market economy. At her weekly press conference yesterday, the House Speaker <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/we-are-free-market-economy-pelosi-rejects-stock-ban-congress-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> she is against any potential bans of Congressional members and their spouses holding or trading individual stocks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The TikTok trader’s queen.</strong> This year, young traders <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/09/21/1039313011/tiktokers-are-trading-stocks-by-watching-what-members-of-congress-do?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">flocked</a> to social media to share their newest investment hack: Nancy Pelosi + Ctrl+C. Because of the STOCK Act, sitting lawmakers can trade individual stocks, but have to disclose their families’ stock trades within 45 days of making them.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Most of the Pelosi household’s trades come from her husband, but she became the face of the “follow the House leader” investing strategy. Taking into account her husband’s assets, Pelosi is one of the wealthiest members of Congress. </span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>49 members of Congress and 182 senior congressional staffers violated the STOCK Act, per an Insider <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/conflicted-congress-key-findings-stock-act-finances-investing-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report</a> published this week. Progressive politicians and angry internet people galore have all spoken out against stock trading by lawmakers, arguing that since they make the rules, they have access to insider knowledge.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COVID
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/JPMorgan-health-care-conference-virtual-omicron?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Health Care’s Hottest Ticket Goes Virtual
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Gathering thousands of health care execs in person? JPMorgan knows that’s probs not the best look with Omicron lurking.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Wednesday, the bank said it <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/jpmorgan-moves-annual-healthcare-conference-to-virtual-after-attendees-drop-out-on-omicron-fear.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t hold</a> its 40th Annual Healthcare Conference in person in San Francisco next month. The event, one of the biggest in the biotech industry, will go virtual instead.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The guest list was getting thin anyways. Industry leaders Moderna and Amgen both bailed on Tuesday, and Alnylam Pharmaceuticals CEO John Maraganore tweeted that the conference “should go virtual to avoid a super-spreader event and a PR disaster for our industry!”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>He may not be exaggerating. The event has been so </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-14/dimon-s-disdain-of-zoom-tested-as-conference-attendees-back-out?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">notoriously crowded</a></span><span> in the past that attendees conducted meetings in the restrooms in 2019.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And at a different health care conference, held by Biogen in Feb. 2020, thousands of people were infected with the coronavirus.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, who usually gives the conference’s keynote speech, probably isn’t psyched about the switch to Zoom—and not because he’s bad at Jackbox games. Dimon's previously said that virtual communications make it harder to close deals and retain customers, and he led a push to partially reopen the bank’s Manhattan office in July.<em>—JW</em></p>
</div>

<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>The UK reported the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/uk-reports-highest-number-of-daily-covid-cases-since-pandemic-began.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most new daily Covid-19 cases</a> on Wednesday (78,610) since the pandemic began, and that number is only expected to rise as the super-contagious Omicron variant spreads across the country. Covid deaths remained low at 165, but experts are worried that surging cases, however mild, could overwhelm hospital systems.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> “It’s time the reign of criminals who are destroying our city, it is time for it to come to an end.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">San Francisco Mayor London Breed <a href="https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2021/12/15/mayor-breed-orders-crackdown-on-crime-in-san-franciscos-tenderloin-neighborhood/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dissed her own city</a> in powerful terms when revealing a new police intervention for the Tenderloin neighborhood, which is suffering from a spike in crime and fentanyl overdoses. A new report out this week showed that California, and the Bay Area in particular, lost residents at an accelerated clip during the pandemic.</p>

</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/leena-nair-luxury-outsider-will-be-the-next-ceo-of-chanel?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Chanel’s New Luxury Outsider
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/leena-nair-luxury-outsider-will-be-the-next-ceo-of-chanel?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Leena Nair" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a77e4db925b8bba083e857e68c17214b5eb36308-1024x675.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Shriya Patil/The The India Today Group via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The luxury fashion brand Chanel picked its newest CEO from a pool that wasn’t filled with $80 perfume. The company <a href="https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2021/12/15/famed-fashion-house-chanel-picks-indian-born-leena-nair-as-ceo?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> that Leena Nair, an exec at the British consumer goods giant Unilever, would replace billionaire co-owner and chairman Alain Wertheimer.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who is Nair?</strong> After joining Unilever 29 years ago, she worked her way up to become the first Asian, first female, and youngest chief human resources officer at the company.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>As the first luxury brand CEO of Indian origin, Nair brings Chanel into the ranks of powerful companies like Google, Microsoft, Adobe, and most recently, Twitter, which are all run by people who grew up in India. </span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Chanel’s decision to hire Nair signals 1) a shift in product priorities—Chanel sells a number of other items including makeup and watches—and 2) a new company culture that values inclusivity. Her appointment will also hopefully help the brand avoid any more <a href="https://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-features/chanel-advent-calendar-tiktok-controversy-response-1235010649/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">out-of-touch advent calendars</a>.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

GAMES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

The Puzzle Section

</a>
</h1>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Mini: </strong>Ready to give your brain a little workout before the workday? <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/brew-mini-thriller?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Play our Mini crossword</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Three Headlines and a Lie</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Three of these news headlines are real and one is faker than your family’s smiles on this year’s holiday card. Can you guess the odd one out?</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>New Jersey man </span><span><a href="https://www.nj.com/news/2021/12/nj-man-pleads-guilty-to-76k-in-chainsaw-thefts-from-amtrak.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pleads</a></span><span> guilty to $76K in chainsaw thefts from Amtrak</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">

color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBehold, the Fed-Tailed Hawk\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/15/fed-makes-a-hawkish-pivot-in-a-bid-to-tame-inflation?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A hawk standing on top of the Federal Reserve building \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/bfe4676b86845cf573a14dc00bbd8854c6788361-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba, \u003ca href=\"https://unsplash.com/@joshuadan\"\u003eOSHUA DANIEL\u003c/a\u003e/Unsplash, Rudy Sulgan/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the Fed flipped the bird: It signaled a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/fed-will-aggressively-dial-back-its-monthly-bond-buying-sees-three-rate-hikes-next-year.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emajor pivot\u003c/a\u003e from a dovish monetary policy (keeping interest rates low, letting the economy run hot) to a hawkish strategy (raising interest rates, slowing down economic growth) in a bid to tamp down surging consumer prices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe central bank said it will reduce its economy-juicing, bond-buying program at double the pace it had originally announced in early November. When it stops purchasing bonds altogether, which will likely be in March, it plans to begin hiking interest rates to cool down the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnd how many hikes will there be? \u003c/strong\u003eMost of the Fed’s 18 officials see at least three rate increases next year, which shows how worried they’ve become about inflation in just the last three months. In September, half of Fed officials believed they wouldn’t have to hike rates at all until 2023.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Inflation has replaced the Covid economic crisis at the top of the Fed’s “must tackle ASAP” list. Here’s why:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eConsumer prices rose at their fastest pace in 39 years in November, and it wasn’t just due to volatile goods, like food and energy. Items across the economy, from rents to home furniture, also rose a concerning amount.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnd this week, producer prices gained at their \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/producer-prices-ppi-inflation-record-f5da5f63-f7bc-45cc-8abd-24a23c30cde9.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efastest pace on record\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Higher prices paid by producers often trickle down and hit consumers’ wallets.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt the same time, job gains have been strong and the unemployment rate has plunged to 4.2%, the lowest level since the pandemic began. “We are making rapid progress towards maximum employment,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e For months, Powell stressed that inflation was “transitory” and related to quirks of the economy reopening. Now he’s sounding a different tune. “The risk of higher inflation becoming entrenched has increased. I don’t think it’s high at this moment, but I think it’s increased,” Powell said. Cue the hawkish pivot.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNancy Pelosi believes that if she wants to YOLO into AMC or Peloton, that’s her right as a citizen in a free market economy. At her weekly press conference yesterday, the House Speaker \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/we-are-free-market-economy-pelosi-rejects-stock-ban-congress-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e she is against any potential bans of Congressional members and their spouses holding or trading individual stocks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe TikTok trader’s queen.\u003c/strong\u003e This year, young traders \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/09/21/1039313011/tiktokers-are-trading-stocks-by-watching-what-members-of-congress-do?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eflocked\u003c/a\u003e to social media to share their newest investment hack: Nancy Pelosi + Ctrl+C. Because of the STOCK Act, sitting lawmakers can trade individual stocks, but have to disclose their families’ stock trades within 45 days of making them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMost of the Pelosi household’s trades come from her husband, but she became the face of the “follow the House leader” investing strategy. Taking into account her husband’s assets, Pelosi is one of the wealthiest members of Congress. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003e49 members of Congress and 182 senior congressional staffers violated the STOCK Act, per an Insider \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/conflicted-congress-key-findings-stock-act-finances-investing-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e published this week. Progressive politicians and angry internet people galore have all spoken out against stock trading by lawmakers, arguing that since they make the rules, they have access to insider color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nHealth Care’s Hottest Ticket Goes Virtual\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGathering thousands of health care execs in person? JPMorgan knows that’s probs not the best look with Omicron lurking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Wednesday, the bank said it \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/jpmorgan-moves-annual-healthcare-conference-to-virtual-after-attendees-drop-out-on-omicron-fear.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewon’t hold\u003c/a\u003e its 40th Annual Healthcare Conference in person in San Francisco next month. The event, one of the biggest in the biotech industry, will go virtual instead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe guest list was getting thin anyways. Industry leaders Moderna and Amgen both bailed on Tuesday, and Alnylam Pharmaceuticals CEO John Maraganore tweeted that the conference “should go virtual to avoid a super-spreader event and a PR disaster for our industry!”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eHe may not be exaggerating. The event has been so \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-14/dimon-s-disdain-of-zoom-tested-as-conference-attendees-back-out?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enotoriously crowded\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in the past that attendees conducted meetings in the restrooms in 2019.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd at a different health care conference, held by Biogen in Feb. 2020, thousands of people were infected with the coronavirus.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eJPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, who usually gives the conference’s keynote speech, probably isn’t psyched about the switch to Zoom—and not because he’s bad at Jackbox games. Dimon's previously said that virtual communications make it harder to close deals and retain customers, and he led a push to partially reopen the bank’s Manhattan office in July.\u003cem\u003e—JW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" picked its newest CEO from a pool that wasn’t filled with $80 perfume. The company \u003ca href=\"https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2021/12/15/famed-fashion-house-chanel-picks-indian-born-leena-nair-as-ceo?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e that Leena Nair, an exec at the British consumer goods giant Unilever, would replace billionaire co-owner and chairman Alain Wertheimer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWho is Nair?\u003c/strong\u003e After joining Unilever 29 years ago, she worked her way up to become the first Asian, first female, and youngest chief human resources officer at the company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs the first luxury brand CEO of Indian origin, Nair brings Chanel into the ranks of powerful companies like Google, Microsoft, Adobe, and most recently, Twitter, which are all run by people who grew up in India. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Chanel’s decision to hire Nair signals 1) a shift in product priorities—Chanel sells a number of other items including makeup and watches—and 2) a new company culture that values inclusivity. Her appointment will also hopefully help the brand avoid any more \u003ca
